questions.question_text: The Query History in the Snowflake Web Interface (UI) is kept for approximately:

A Snowflake query took 40 minutes to run. The results indicate that ‘Bytes spilled to local storage’ was a large number.

What is the issue and how can it be resolved?

choices.B: The warehouse is too small. Increase the size of the warehouse to reduce the spillage.
choices.C: The Snowflake console has timed-out. Contact Snowflake Support.
choices.A: The warehouse is too large. Decrease the size of the warehouse to reduce the spillage.
choices.D: The warehouse consists of a single cluster. Use a multi-cluster warehouse to reduce the spillage.

discussion.content: Answer is B. warehouse size should be increased. multi cluster warehouse will just help in increasing paralelism.
The correct answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/performance-query-warehouse-memory#:~:text=When%20memory%20spillage,causing%20the%20spillage.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
https://github.com/dbt-labs/docs.getdbt.com/discussions/1550
When you have spillage, increasing warehouse size almost always helps.
The answer should be B since this needs to be solved by scale up, not scale out.
Answer is D

questions.question_text: What is the MOST efficient way to load streaming data into Snowflake?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Correct

The correct answer is B.
Use Snowpipe: Load streaming 
Use the COPY command: Batch loading

Selected Answer: D
Streaming Data in Snowflake is Change Data Capture. So you need a Stream object for it.

The MOST efficient way to load streaming data into Snowflake is to use Snowpipe (option B). Snowpipe is a native, automated data ingestion service within Snowflake that can continuously load data from various sources in near real-time.

Selected Answer: C
"You can use the OBJECT_CONSTRUCT function combined with the COPY command to convert the rows in a relational table to a single VARIANT column and unload the rows into a file."
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/data-unload-considerations

Selected Answer: C
Correct

Selected Answer: C
Option D will also be correct if Decompressed is written instead of compressed at the end of statement.

comments.content:
COMPRESSION option can't be set to TRUE

-- If FILE_FORMAT = ( TYPE = CSV ... )
 COMPRESSION = AUTO | GZIP | BZ2 | BROTLI | ZSTD | DEFLATE | RAW_DEFLATE | NONE

-- If FILE_FORMAT = ( TYPE = JSON ... )
 COMPRESSION = AUTO | GZIP | BZ2 | BROTLI | ZSTD | DEFLATE | RAW_DEFLATE | NONE

-- If FILE_FORMAT = ( TYPE = PARQUET ... )
 COMPRESSION = AUTO | LZO | SNAPPY | NONE
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/copy-into-location
had option D said 'can be uncompressed', then it'll be true. i.e specify compression method/extension for 'decompression'

questions.question_text: Which COPY INTO statement accurately describes how to unload data from a Snowflake table?

choices.C: The OBJECT_CONSTRUCT function can be combined with the COPY command to convert the rows in a relational table to a single VARIANT column.
choices.D: If the COMPRESSION option is set to TRUE, a file's name can be specified with the appropriate file extension so that the output file can be compressed.
choices.B: By default, COPY INTO [location] statements do not separate table data into a set of output files.
choices.A: The default value for the SINGLE option is set to TRUE.
